title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.1-2 | 05-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: ओम अज्ञानति मिरान्धस्य ज्ञानान्जनिषलाकया चक्षुरुन्मीलितं येनातस्मै श्रीगुरवेनमहा नमाओम विष्णुपादाया कृष्णप्रेष्ठायभूतले श्रीमते भक्ति वेदान्त स्वामिन्नितिनामिने नमस्ते सारस्वते देवे गउरवाणी प्र
वैतगदाधरा श्रीवासाधी गउरभक्त वृण्धा हरे कृष्णा हरे कृष्णा कृष्ण कृष्णा हरे हरे हरे रामा हरे रामा रामा रामा हरे हरे
OM NAMO BHAGVATE VASUDEVAYA NARAYANAM NAMASKRITYA NARAM CHAIVANAROTTAMAM DEVIM SARASVATIM VYASAM TATO JAYAM UDI RAYET
In this session we will be discussing from a new chapter, 7th chapter of the first canto of Bhagavatam.
The 7th chapter is entitled, The Son of Drona Punished.
And we will be beginning with the first verse.
SHAUNAKA VACHA NIRGATE NARADE SUTA BHHAGAVAN BHADARAYANAH SHRUTAVAM STAD ABHIPRETAM TATAKHIM AKAROD VIBHUHU
The meaning of this verse is, Rishi Shaunaka asked,
O Suta!
The great and transcendentally powerful Vyasa Deva heard everything from Shri Narada Muni.
So after Narada's departure, what did Vyasa Deva do?
If you remember the conversation between the sages of Naimisharanya headed by Shaunaka Rishi
and Suta Goswami is the beginning of the first chapter of the first canto of Bhagavatam, the opening of the Bhagavatam.
So, seeing the eagerness of these sages to hear about Krishna, Suta Goswami decided to recite the Bhagavatam, which he had heard from Shukadeva Goswami.
So before reciting the Bhagavatam, Shaunaka Rishi asked many other questions apart from the first six questions to Suta Goswami.
So,
in response to questions asked by Shaunaka Rishi, who is the representative of the sages of Naimisharanya,
Suta Goswami is answering.
Here, Shaunaka Rishi is asking to continue, what did Vyasa Deva do?
After he heard everything about Narada Muni's previous birth, how Narada Muni actually got enlightenment from the Bhaktived Centers,
How Narada Muni actually got enlightenment from the Bhaktived neben 크리ंת мед화�рост,
How Narada Muni actually got enlightenment from the Bhaktivedוכ Schulta 반� phenomenal imprudence need to be practiced from the teachings of the Vedants,
How he practice this Dharma practice, which is the Quit Heria.
How he practiced this Dharma practice which is the realization of the teaching of the Sovak Sangha,
How he practiced this Dharma practice, which is theening to the últimaibly strong dedication of theic sages.

he practiced going to a sacred place, the meditation on the Supreme Lord, how he had a brief glimpse of the darshan of the Lord, then the Lord spoke to him, and then he became perfect, and when he quit his body in his previous life, he changed from a material body to a completely spiritual body, and in that spiritual body now, in this day of Brahma, he is born as the son of Brahma,

in his same transcendental form, and he travels everywhere simply singing the glories of the Supreme Lord, while vibrating on his transcendental instrument, the Veena, which is given to him by Krishna himself, and in this way, he is himself completely enlivened, and he enlivens others also.

Now, after Narada's departure, what did Vyasa Deva do? That's the question now, Savanaka Rishi is raising. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, in this chapter, the clue for describing Srimad Bhagavatam is picked up, as Maharaj Pariksit is miraculously saved in the womb of his mother.
Now, Bhagavatam begins from the point where the end of the battle of Kurukshetra,
Pariksit, see the central personalities for the recitation of the Bhagavatam, first time, is Pariksit Maharaj, who inquired from Shukadeva Goswami.
Shukadeva Goswami learned the Bhagavatam from Vyasa Deva.
Vyasa Deva compiled the Bhagavatam after hearing about Narada's instructions on Bhagavatam.

So, that is the link. Now, the narration will begin by Suta Goswami about the Bhagavatam, how Pariksit was saved in the womb of his mother, and that is the description of the birth and activities of Pariksit Maharaj, which was inquired to Suta Goswami.

Now, this reason for Pariksit being saved in the womb of his mother was because the cause was Ashwatthama, the son of Dronacharya, who killed the five sons of Draupadi while they were asleep, for which he was punished by Arjuna.
That is the incident that is going to be narrated.
In this chapter, in the seventh chapter, the son of Drona punished. By whom? By Arjuna.
Because the son of Drona, Ashwatthama, he killed the five sleeping sons of Draupadi towards the end of the Battle of Kurukshetra.
Before commencing the great epic, Srimad Bhagavatam, Shri Vyasa Deva realized the whole truth by trance and devotion.
Vyasa Deva sat in meditation and followed the Holy Spirit.

Following Narada Muni's instructions to compile Bhagavatam, he realized the entire truth about Krishna, which is going to be described by Vyasa Deva while compiling the Bhagavatam, and Vyasa Deva is going to teach it to his own son, Shukadeva Goswami, who is already a liberated soul.
So, we will hear now systematically about Vyasa Deva realizing the truth.
So, we will hear now systematically about Vyasa Deva realizing the truth.
The second verse.
The meaning of this second verse of the same seventh chapter of the first canto of Bhagavatam.
Shri Suta said.
Suta Goswami is now responding to the question.
On the western bank of the river Saraswati, which is intimately related with the Vedas, there is a cottage for meditation at Shamyaprasa, which enlivens the transcendental activities of the sages.
So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says,
For spiritual advancement of knowledge, a suitable place and atmosphere are definitely required.
The place on the...
The western bank of the Saraswati river is especially suitable for this purpose, and there is the ashram of Vyasa Deva at Shamyaprasa.
So, the place where Vyasa Deva's ashram was located is a very, very holy place, a sacred place, most suitable for spiritual activities.
The place on the western bank of the Saraswati river is especially suitable for this purpose, and there is the ashram of Vyasa Deva at Shamyaprasa.

hills of the Himalayas and even other places there devotees do visit that
place it's called Vyasa Gufa the cave of Vyasa Deva that's the literal meaning in
Hindi Vyasa Gufa so that place that is the place where Vyasa Deva's ashram is
located and Vyasa Deva sat there and engaged in meditation and when he was
and had reached Samadhi he was able to actually realize the entire truth about
the absolute personality of Godhead Krishna that will be described now now
Srila Vyasa Deva was a householder
that's how he had a son Sukhdev Goswami yet his residential place is called an
ashram so what is ashram and ashram is a place where spiritual culture is
always foremost ashram is a residential place but it is a spiritually
surcharged place because it is the most suitable
place for
such a spiritual place but it is a a place where you are32
spiritual shelter for any transcendentalist it is necessary to reside in a place where spiritual culture is foremost
that means a transcendentalist does not live in any place simply for engaging in some sense enjoyment
a transcendentalist voluntarily gives up sense enjoyment in order to cultivate spiritual life
so Vyasa Deva of course is perfect because he is the empowered incarnation of the Supreme Lord for compiling all the Vedic literature
and he has appeared for this purpose specifically
he says
also an incarnation of the Lord
Shakya Vesha Avatar
so he has no need to practice
but nonetheless to set an example
he is situated in his ashram
and he is performing meditation
in order to fix his mind on the absolute personality of Godhead
the absolute truth
and realize the whole subject matter of the Bhagavad Gita
before compiling
Srila Prabhupada further explains
it does not matter whether the place belongs to a householder or a mendicant
mendicant means somebody who is a renunciant
who is a tapasvi
who is a renounced order of life
the whole varnashrama system is so designed
that each and every status of life is called an ashram
varana ashrama
four varanas
brahmana, kshatriya, vaishya, shudra
this defines the whole system of life
this defines the occupational duty
of four different classes of people
in the civilized human society
apart from these four varanas
there are four ashramas
what are the four ashramas?
brahmachari ashram
grihastha ashram
vanaprastha ashram
sannyas ashram
these are four stages
of gradual progress towards the ultimate goal of self realization
while spiritual culture is very prominent
in each of these stages of ashram life
all are spiritual shelter
brahmachari stays in the house of the spiritual master
the guru
guru kula
and he is taught the vedic knowledge
and then grihastha, householder
householder, he lives with his wife
and children, family life
but he is engaged in spiritual activities
even as a householder
and of course after completing his duty as a householder
he hands over charge of the house
to his grown up son or some other guardian
and he leaves home and goes away to the forest or a holy place
to intensify his spiritual practice
and become completely engaged in activities of self realization
which is the ultimate goal of life
to realize the self
and finally sannyas ashram is when one is completely renounced
and one simply engages exclusively in spiritual activities
either one has already realized
or one is just waiting to perfect his realization
especially in the sannyas ashram
so this means, Prabhupada says further
spiritual culture is the common factor for all
the brahmacharis, the grihasthas, the vanaprasthas and sannyasis
all belong to the same mission of life
namely realization of the supreme
see important thing is self realization means
I am also self, individual self
jivatma
but there is a supreme self
the supreme paramatma
krishna
the supreme personality of god
so realization of krishna is the ultimate self realization
therefore none of them are less important as far as spiritual culture is concerned
the difference is the formality on the strength of renunciation
different rules and different formalities are there
but ultimately all are meant for
ultimate realization
of the supreme personality of god krishna
the sannyasis are held in high estimation
on the strength of practical renunciation
the sannyasis set the example
by practicing the high standard of renunciation
which is befitting them
who are completely dedicated for spiritual practice
or spiritual life
I will stop here
thank you very much
Hare Krishna
